The Wolf's Cookbook

Food By Geeks, For Geeks

A distinctly western take on the classic dish from India. Depending on the spices used it can very from mild to "wheres the milk ?" spicy. This recipe is constantly in flux and changing as I learn more about cooking and what flavors truly blend well together.

Ingredients

  • Meats
    • 1 pound Sausage
    • 1 pound Mild Chorizo (preferably a Mexican variety)
    • 4 slices Thick Cut Bacon (diced)
  • Vegetables
    • 1 Medium White Onion
    • 1 Large Green Bell Pepper
    • 1½ cups Sprint Onion (chopped)
    • ½ cup Daikon Radish (diced)
    • 3 cloves Garlic (minced)
      • I have been known to use a considerable amount more
  • Grains
    • 1 cup Rice (uncooked)
      • Any type of rice can be used, but some (such as Brown Rice) might need specific preparation not covered here
      • You can substitute noodles of a similar amount here
      • The steps involving the saffron can be omitted - and probably should if you use noodles instead of rice
  • Spices
    • 1 tsp Sage
    • 1 tsp Oregano
    • ½ tsp Thyme
    • ¼ tsp Marjoram
    • ¼ tsp Chinese Five Spice Powder
      • This is a classic Chinese cooking spice blend - you should be able to find it at any decent grocers
    • ¼ tsp Powdered Lemon Grass
    • ⅛ gram Saffron (powder)
  • Wet Spices
    • 1 tbsp Curry Paste
      • I currently prefer Masaman Yellow, but any variety can be used
    • ½ tsp Pho Paste/Base
    • ½ tsp Boullon Paste (beef)
      • I use "Better than Boullon" brand, but feel free to use your favorite
  • Liquids
    • 2 tbsp Mirin
    • 2 tsp Honey
      • Try substituting Agave Nectar for a change of pace
    • 3 tbsp Soy Sauce
      • If you're concerned about sodium, you can use the low-sodium version
    • 1 tsp (Toasted) Sesame Oil
    • 2 cups Water
      • Adjust the amount of water to match how much is recommended for the type of rice you are using
      • Basmati Rice, for instance, only needs 1½ cups of water per cup of uncooked rice

Instructions

  1. In a small bowl mix the Mirin, Soy Sauce, Sesame Oil and Honey
  2. Mix into that mixture of liquids the Pho, Curry and Boillon pastes. Set this aside for later
  3. Over a medium-low heat toast the remaining spices (not the Saffron)
  4. Add the vegetables and 1 teaspoon of your choice of cooking oil. Sautee until the vegetables start to "wilt" but stop before they begin to caramelize
  5. Add the meats to the pan and cook well, breaking up the sausage and chorizo until everything is finely distributed
  6. When meat is about half done, start cooking the rice in the water
  7. When meat is done, add the paste-like liquid mixture that was set aside earlier. Use a silicone or rubber spatula to get as much as possible into the pot. Mix well, cover the pot and turn down the heat
  8. When the rice is done, mix in the Saffron. The rice will turn a nice yellow-orange color
  9. Add the rice to the pot, mix well and let simmer, uncovered, at a medium-low heat until it begins to thicken. When it thickens up a bit, it is ready to serve
  • If the curry is still too soupy, add a teaspoon or two of flour, corn starch or mung bean starch (only 1 of these is needed!)
